title: [ER] Better wrong brackets recovery heuristics for error messages?

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
This is a diagnostic enhancement request, but it's rather vague, so if you think it isn't actionable, I'll close it down.

Generally I find the rustc compiler quite helpful at spotting problems in my code. One of the few (small) pain points it gives me is when a bracket is missing (or a stray one is added), this sometimes happens when I translate some Python code to Rust, or when I add some calls to macros that need brackets (like foo!{...}).

In the last of such cases I got an error message like:

```rust
error: unexpected closing delimiter: `}`
   --> ...\some_program.rs:636:1
    |
12  | fn main() {
    |           - this opening brace...
...
619 |     }
    |     - ...matches this closing brace
...
636 | }
    | ^ unexpected closing delimiter

error: aborting due to previous error
```

The problem was at line 361 and to find it I have had to comment-out chunks of code in some kind of binary search :-( Similar situations have happened to me several times in the last years of coding in Rust.

Assuming my Rust code is indented well enough, the question is: it's possible to improve the parser heuristics to give some hints were the brackets problem could be?
